page.title: 02CONSERVATION OF SAND DUNES
page.content: The sand dunes, running parallel to West Sands Road, end just before Out Head,the road being built on the disused rubbish tip for St.Andrews. They have been worn down by wind coming off the sea, and by frequent public use of the area. Hollows in some of the dunes have been formed by erosion and are used as picnic areas. Over the years, the dunes have moved about 100 yards further inland and the sea has encroached so that land is being rapidly eroded. To preserve the dunes nearer the town, they have been fenced in to prevent the public from using them as a sheltered picnic area. Spruce trees have also been planted to discourage people from using the area. Plants such as Sea Lyme and Marram Grass are common and help to stabilize the dunes.
